questions.text: Which fundamental principle distinguishes MRI from CT?

options.B: MRI is based on radiofrequency excitation of nuclei

questions.explanation: The slide "Principles of Tomographic Imaging" shows MRI using radiofrequency excitation, unlike CT which is transmission-based using X-rays.

questions.text: In which part of the electromagnetic spectrum does MRI operate?
questions.explanation: The slide "Electromagnetic Spectrum: MRI, X-Ray, Optical" places MR imaging in the radiofrequency range.

questions.text: What is the primary motivation for using MRI in clinical imaging?

options.C: No ionizing radiation and excellent biological contrast

questions.explanation: Slide "Motivation – Why MRI?": lists "No ionizing radiation" and "High biological contrast" as key advantages.

questions.text: Who first described the principle of nuclear magnetic resonance?
questions.explanation: The "History" slide states: "1946 Felix Bloch and Edward Purcell: principle of nuclear magnetic resonance."

questions.text: What key contribution did Paul Lauterbur make to MRI?
questions.explanation: The history slide credits Paul Lauterbur with "spatial encoding" and NMR zeugmatography.

questions.text: What physical property allows certain nuclei to be detected by MRI?
questions.explanation: Slide "Basic NMR Physics 1": "Quantum physics tells us that an atomic nucleus has a magnetic moment."

questions.text: What determines the Larmor frequency ω?

options.C: Magnetic field strength and gyromagnetic ratio

questions.explanation: The slide states: "ω = γ · B" where γ is the gyromagnetic ratio and B the magnetic field.

questions.text: Why is hydrogen (¹H) the most important nucleus for MRI?

options.B: It has the strongest magnetic field
options.C: It is abundant in biological tissue

questions.explanation: The spatial encoding slides emphasize that MRI relies mainly on water protons due to their abundance.

questions.text: Why is the net magnetization in MRI very small?

options.B: Only a small population difference exists

questions.explanation: Slide "Basic NMR Physics 2": "Under typical conditions, the net excess is only in the ppm range."

questions.text: What role does the RF pulse play in MRI?

options.C: Excites spins to a higher energy state

questions.explanation: Slide "Basic NMR Physics 3": external RF "brings some spins into the anti-parallel state."

questions.text: What is detected by the MRI receiver coil?

options.B: RF energy emitted by relaxing spins

questions.explanation: The slide notes that emitted quanta are detected "by an antenna."

questions.text: What does T1 relaxation describe?
questions.explanation: Slide "Relaxation T1": T1 is the longitudinal (spin-lattice) relaxation.

questions.text: What does T2 relaxation describe?
questions.explanation: Slide "Relaxation 1": T2 corresponds to transversal (spin-spin) relaxation.

questions.text: What is Free Induction Decay (FID)?
questions.explanation: Slide "Relaxation 4": "What we observe is called free induction decay (FID)."

questions.text: Why is a spin-echo sequence used?

options.B: To reverse dephasing caused by field inhomogeneities

questions.explanation: Slide "NMR Spectroscopy": "Dephasing – reversal by spin echo!"

questions.text: Which RF pulses are used in a classic spin-echo sequence?
questions.explanation: The slide "Spin-Echo-Sequence" explicitly shows a 90° pulse followed by a 180° pulse.

questions.text: What enables spatial encoding in MRI?
questions.explanation: The "Spatial Encoding" slides explain that gradients make resonance frequency position-dependent.

questions.text: What is the purpose of slice selection?

options.C: Excite spins only at a specific z-position

questions.explanation: Slide "Spatial Encoding – Selecting a slice": only spins at a specific z position are excited.

questions.text: What does phase encoding achieve?
questions.explanation: Slide "Phase encoding": spins acquire position-dependent phase shifts.

questions.text: What does frequency encoding correspond to?
questions.explanation: Slide "Frequency encoding": water molecules emit radiation with spatially varying frequency.

questions.text: What is k-space?
questions.explanation: Slides on "K-Space: Image Contrast & Resolution" describe k-space as the Fourier domain.

questions.text: Which part of k-space mainly determines image contrast?
questions.explanation: The k-space slides indicate contrast information is concentrated in the center.

questions.text: Which part of k-space mainly determines spatial resolution?
questions.explanation: Resolution is linked to high spatial frequencies located at the outer k-space.

questions.text: What mathematical operation reconstructs the MR image from k-space?
questions.explanation: Slide "Image Reconstruction": a 2D FFT yields the desired image.

questions.text: Why does MRI provide high biological contrast?

options.B: Due to tissue-specific T1 and T2 values

questions.explanation: Slides on contrast mechanisms state T1 and T2 values are tissue-specific and reflect biochemical properties.

questions.text: What is the effect of gadolinium-based contrast agents?
questions.explanation: Slides "Contrast Mechanisms": Gd-DTPA "reduce locally the T1 times."

questions.text: What distinguishes gradient echo from spin echo sequences?

options.C: Gradient echo does not refocus field inhomogeneities

questions.explanation: Slide "Gradient Echo": states gradient echo does not refocus main field inhomogeneity.

questions.text: What is a major disadvantage of gradient echo imaging?
questions.explanation: The slide lists artifacts "especially between haemorrhages and normal tissue."

questions.text: What causes foldover (aliasing) artifacts?
questions.explanation: Slide "Artefacts – Foldover": signals outside the FOV are mapped back incorrectly.

questions.text: What is the main idea of SENSE parallel imaging?

options.C: Reduce phase encoding steps using coil sensitivities

questions.explanation: Slide "Technical Advances: SENSE": fewer phase encoding steps are compensated using coil sensitivity.

questions.text: Why does parallel imaging reduce scan time?
questions.explanation: SENSE reduces acquisition time "by the amount of coil elements."

questions.text: Why is MRI called a "physic’s sensor for biological properties"?

options.C: It reflects tissue biochemistry via relaxation

questions.explanation: This phrase appears explicitly in the "Take home messages" slide.

questions.text: What does "white is not white and black is not black" mean in MRI?
questions.explanation: The slide emphasizes that contrast can be changed arbitrarily using TR, TE, and sequences.

questions.text: Why can MRI be scaled from mice to humans?
questions.explanation: The final take-home message states MRI is "scalable from mice to men."

questions.text: What overarching message does the lecture convey about MRI?

options.C: MRI offers almost arbitrary contrast through physics

questions.explanation: The final slide highlights "Almost arbitrary contrast variable" as a key message.
